metadata.case_name: Owner of Sri Brahannayaki Theatre v. State of Madras

facts.text: Appellant is the owner of a permanent cinema theatre called Sri Brahannayaki in Tiruthuraipundi, Tanjore District.

Appellant held a licence from the District Magistrate, Tanjore, with effect from September 5, 1950, to September 4, 1951. The licence is granted for one year at a time and is renewable from year to year.

Licence imposed conditions pursuant to G.O. Mis. 1054, Home, dated 28th March, 1948, and G.O. Mis. 3422, dated 15th September, 1948, issued by the State of Madras under section 8 of the Cinematograph Act of 1918.

Condition 4(a): The licensee shall exhibit at each performance one or more approved films of such length and for such length of time, as the Provincial Government or the Central Government may, by general or special order, direct. The licensee shall comply with such directions as the Provincial Government may by general or special order give as to the manner in which approved films shall be exhibited in the course of any performance. Explanation: Approved Films means a cinematograph film approved for the purpose of this condition by the Provincial Government or the Central Government.
Special condition 3: The licensee should exhibit at the commencement of each performance not less than 2,000 feet of one or more approved films.

Appellant objected to the conditions and moved the High Court of Judicature at Madras under article 226 of the Constitution for an order or direction to the District Magistrate, Tanjore, to delete the said conditions from his licence and to the State of Madras to rescind the notifications.

Madras High Court in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 5744 of 1951 by Judgment and Order dated 24th August, 1951, rejected both contentions, holding that the conditions imposed were reasonable and were in the interests of the general public. Granted leave to appeal to this Court.
Appeal to Supreme Court under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

Madras Cinematograph Rules, 1933, were amended by notification G.O. Mis. 1054, Home, dated March 28, 1948, in exercise of powers conferred by section 8 of the Cinematograph Act, 1918 (Central Act II of 1918), inserting the impugned conditions in place of condition 4 of the licence in Form A.

Approved films are those films which are either produced by the Government or are purchased from private producers. Government purchases from private producers who lack marketing machinery and charges hire from cinema licensees.
Exhibition of a film generally takes 2 hours and a quarter.
Showing of a film of 2,000 feet will take about 20 minutes, which is about 1/7th of the total time of each performance if taken to last for 2-1/4 hours.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notifications and conditions are beyond the competence of the Government of Madras and the District Magistrate.
Whether the conditions, as being outside the scope of the Cinematograph Act, amount to reasonable restrictions imposed in the interest of the general public under article 19(6).

petitioner_arguments.text: The notifications and conditions are ultra vires and beyond the powers of the licensing authority.
The conditions contravene freedom of speech and expression under article 19(1)(a) and right to carry on trade or business under article 19(1)(g).

respondent_arguments.text: The conditions imposed were reasonable and were in the interests of the general public.

court_reasoning.text: Appeal disposed of on second ground without going into competence under the Act. Condition 4(a) vests Government with unregulated discretion as neither length of film nor time is specified, allowing compulsion to exhibit films consuming whole or major part of performance time (2 hours 15 min). No principle guides discretion, leading to loss or extinction of business. Condition savours of imposition, not restriction. Does not specify educational/instructional character.
court_reasoning.key_observation: A condition couched in such wide language is bound to operate harshly upon the cinema business and cannot be regarded as a reasonable restriction.

court_reasoning.text: Special condition 3 requires minimum 2000 feet (about 20 min, 1/7th time) at commencement with no maximum, allowing Government to compel exhibition of much longer films (e.g., 10,000-12,000 feet), pushing out licensee's film. Unrestrained discretion leads to unjustifiable interference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Here again no maximum limit having been imposed it follows that the discretion of the authority is unrestrained and unfettered.

holdings.text: Condition 4(a) amounts to an unreasonable restriction on the right to carry on business under article 19(1)(g) and is void.
Special condition 3 is equally obnoxious and must be deleted as void against article 19(1)(g).

statutes_cited.name: Cinematograph Act, 1918
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers State Government to make rules for carrying into effect the provisions of the Act, including amendment of Madras Cinematograph Rules, 1933.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for appeal, writ petition, fundamental rights claimed violated, and test for reasonable restrictions.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed. Condition 4(a) and special condition 3 held void and of no legal effect against fundamental right under article 19(1)(g). No opinion expressed on first contention regarding competence.
outcome.relief_granted: Impugned conditions deleted from licence (implicitly by declaration of invalidity).

key_quotes.text: "A condition couched in such wide language is bound to operate harshly upon the cinema business and cannot be regarded as a reasonable restriction. It savours more of the nature of an imposition than a restriction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on unreasonableness of condition 4(a).

key_quotes.text: "Here again no maximum limit having been imposed it follows that the discretion of the authority is unrestrained and unfettered and must lead to an unjustifiable interference with the right of the licensee to carry on his business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
